title: National Information Technology Authority (Amendment) Bill
summary:
The National Information Technology Authority (Amendment) Bill establishes a comprehensive regulatory framework for Ghana's ICT sector by creating the National Information Technology Authority (NITA) as an independent statutory body with extensive powers over licensing, certification, standards-setting, and enforcement. The bill replaces the previous National Information Technology Agency and introduces mandatory licensing for all ICT businesses and certification for ICT professionals working in both public and private sectors.

**Regulatory Structure and Requirements:** The bill requires **mandatory licensing** for anyone conducting ICT-related business, including infrastructure installation and service development ([34](#34-requirement-for-licence)). All **ICT professionals must obtain certification** from the Authority ([44](#44-certification-of-ict-professionals)), and public institutions must secure **technical clearance** before starting major ICT projects ([49](#49-compliance-monitoring-and-technical-clearance)). The Authority establishes a **National Digital Architecture** to standardize how government ICT systems operate and interconnect ([50](#50-national-digital-architecture)) and maintains an **ICT Project Registry** requiring public institutions to register all technology projects before commencement ([51](#51-ict-project-registry)). These requirements create a formalized regulatory environment that enhances sector professionalism and coordination but significantly increases compliance obligations and operational costs for ICT businesses.

**Innovation and Business Environment:** The bill includes **progressive provisions** designed to balance regulation with innovation. It establishes a **regulatory sandbox** allowing innovators to test new ICT products and services under supervision with temporary regulatory relief ([56](#56-regulatory-sandbox-for-ict-innovation)) and adopts a **risk-based and principles-oriented regulatory approach** that prioritizes consumer protection while encouraging flexibility ([57](#57-risk-based-and-principles-oriented-approach)). The Authority must create regulations that are **technology-neutral** and regularly update rules to accommodate emerging technologies like artificial intelligence and blockchain ([58](#58-future-technologies-and-adaptive-regulation)). A **Multi-Stakeholder Advisory Forum** provides policy input from industry, civil society, and academia ([60](#60-multi-stakeholder-advisory-forum)), and regulations must be **reviewed every five years** with public consultation ([61](#61-periodic-review-of-regulatory-instruments)). However, the mandatory licensing regime, certification requirements, and technical clearance processes create substantial **barriers to entry** and may slow innovation despite these flexibility mechanisms. The bill also mandates **digital inclusion initiatives** targeting people with disabilities, women, rural populations, and marginalized groups ([59](#59-digital-inclusion-and-accessibility)).

**Enforcement Powers and Penalties:** The Authority possesses **extensive enforcement powers** that raise proportionality concerns. Inspectors can **enter and investigate premises**, inspect records, and **seize ICT products or equipment** suspected of illegal use ([65](#65-power-of-an-inspector)). The Authority can **close businesses or facilities** that pose risks to public health, safety, or the environment, or fail to meet service standards—typically with 15 days' notice but immediately in cases of danger ([46](#46-closure-of-premises-or-facility)). **Criminal penalties** include fines between 2,000 and 5,000 penalty units and imprisonment between 6 months and 2 years for offenses such as operating without a license, providing false information, or obstructing inspectors ([84](#84-general-offences-and-penalties), [86](#86-offences-relating-to-licensing-and-certification), [66](#66-obstruction-of-an-inspector)). The Authority can impose **administrative penalties** between 20,000 and 50,000 penalty units for non-compliance, with power to suspend or revoke licenses if fines remain unpaid ([90](#90-administrative-penalty)). While these enforcement mechanisms aim to ensure compliance and protect consumers, the combination of criminal sanctions including imprisonment for regulatory violations, broad seizure powers, and substantial administrative penalties creates a **heavy-handed enforcement regime** that may disproportionately impact smaller businesses and stifle entrepreneurship.

**Governance and Accountability:** The bill establishes governance mechanisms including a **Board of Directors** appointed by the President with at least three women members ([8](#8-governing-body-of-the-authority)), operational **independence from external direction** except as specified in the Act ([16](#16-independence-of-the-authority)), and a **Dispute Resolution Committee** and **National Information Technology Tribunal** for appeals ([72](#72-dispute-resolution-committee), [76](#76-establishment-of-the-national-information-technology-authority-tribunal)). The Authority must maintain **transparency** through annual reports, public engagement, and a public Register of Interests for Board members ([29](#29-annual-report-and-other-reports), [97](#97-public-engagement), [94](#94-register-of-interests)). Funding sources include Parliamentary allocations, customs duties on ICT equipment, service fees, communications service tax portions, and regulatory fees ([23](#23-funds-of-the-authority)). The bill creates an **e-government ICT infrastructure company** to manage government technology systems and reduce reliance on external contractors ([31](#31-establishment-of-the-e-government-ict-infrastructure-company)). These provisions establish institutional checks and balances, though the concentration of regulatory, enforcement, and adjudicatory powers within a single Authority raises questions about separation of functions and potential for regulatory overreach.

description.analysis:
The National Information Technology Authority (Amendment) Bill creates a **fundamentally restrictive environment for digital innovation** despite including some progressive provisions. While the bill establishes a **regulatory sandbox framework** ([56](#56-regulatory-sandbox-for-ict-innovation)) to allow controlled testing of new ICT products and services with temporary regulatory relief, and grants the Authority powers to **fund training and promote research** ([6](#6-powers-of-the-authority)), these innovation-friendly mechanisms are severely undermined by the bill's heavy-handed regulatory architecture. The **mandatory licensing requirement** for all ICT businesses ([34](#34-requirement-for-licence)) and **mandatory certification** for all ICT professionals in both public and private sectors ([44](#44-certification-of-ict-professionals)) create substantial barriers to entry that will disproportionately impact startups, solo entrepreneurs, and small technology companies—the very actors who typically drive innovation in digital ecosystems.

The bill's **enforcement regime poses severe risks** that will create a chilling effect on innovation and entrepreneurship. Innovators face **criminal penalties including imprisonment** of 6 months to 2 years for operating without proper licenses or certifications ([86](#86-offences-relating-to-licensing-and-certification)), and up to 5-7 years for various compliance failures ([91](#91-other-offences)). **Administrative penalties** ranging from 20,000 to 50,000 penalty units can be imposed for non-compliance, with the Authority empowered to suspend or revoke licenses if fines remain unpaid ([90](#90-administrative-penalty)). The **non-transferability of licenses** without prior approval, backed by penalties of 5-10 years imprisonment ([40](#40-non-transferability-of-licence)), restricts business flexibility and makes it difficult for innovative startups to attract investment or execute exit strategies. Additionally, **corporate officers and shareholders are personally liable** for company violations unless they prove due diligence ([89](#89-offence-by-a-body-corporate)), creating personal risk that will deter talented individuals from joining or leading innovative ventures.

The cumulative effect of these provisions is a **risk-averse regulatory environment** that prioritizes control over innovation. While established companies with legal and compliance resources may navigate these requirements, the regulatory burden will effectively exclude many potential innovators—particularly young entrepreneurs, informal sector participants, and those in underserved communities—from participating in Ghana's digital economy. The threat of **random audits** ([69](#69-other-enforcement-measures)) and the possibility of **immediate suspension** for various violations ([41](#41-suspension-of-licence)) will discourage the experimentation and risk-taking essential to innovation. Although the regulatory sandbox offers some relief, it cannot offset the broader chilling effect of a regime where regulatory missteps can result in imprisonment, substantial fines, and permanent exclusion from the ICT sector.

This bill fundamentally transforms Ghana's ICT business environment by introducing **comprehensive mandatory licensing and certification requirements** that create substantial barriers to entry and ongoing compliance burdens. Every person engaging in ICT-related business—including infrastructure installation and service development—must obtain a license from the Authority ([34](#34-requirement-for-licence)), while all ICT professionals in both public and private sectors must secure certification ([44](#44-certification-of-ict-professionals)). These requirements are reinforced by **performance standards and certification tiers** that public institutions must verify before procurement ([54](#54-ict-performance-standards-and-certification-tiers)). While these measures aim to professionalize the sector and ensure quality standards, they impose significant **time and cost burdens** that will disproportionately impact startups, small businesses, and individual entrepreneurs who may lack resources to navigate complex regulatory processes.

The **enforcement regime creates substantial business risks** through a combination of criminal penalties, administrative sanctions, and operational restrictions. Operating without proper licensing or certification carries fines of 1,000-5,000 penalty units and **imprisonment of six months to two years** ([86](#86-offences-relating-to-licensing-and-certification))—making regulatory violations criminal offenses rather than purely administrative matters. The Authority can impose **administrative penalties up to 50,000 penalty units** for non-compliance and suspend or revoke licenses if fines remain unpaid ([90](#90-administrative-penalty)). License suspension can occur for numerous reasons including failure to comply with directives, financial obligations, or service standards ([41](#41-suspension-of-licence)), creating ongoing uncertainty for businesses. The bill extends liability to **corporate officers, directors, and shareholders** unless they prove due diligence ([89](#89-offence-by-a-body-corporate)), and prohibits license transfers without prior approval under severe penalties including 5-10 years imprisonment ([40](#40-non-transferability-of-licence)). Random ICT audits ([69](#69-other-enforcement-measures)) and extensive penalties for various violations ([91](#91-other-offences)) further compound compliance risks.

Despite these restrictive elements, the bill includes **limited provisions to support innovation and business development**. The Authority gains powers to promote and fund training, undertake research, and support ICT industry development ([6](#6-powers-of-the-authority)). Most significantly, a **Regulatory Sandbox Framework** allows eligible innovators to test new products and services in a controlled environment with temporary regulatory relief ([56](#56-regulatory-sandbox-for-ict-innovation)), providing a pathway for experimentation despite the otherwise rigid regulatory structure. However, these positive provisions are discretionary and limited in scope compared to the mandatory compliance requirements affecting all market participants. The overall effect is a **significantly more restrictive business environment** that prioritizes regulatory control and standardization over entrepreneurial flexibility, likely reducing market dynamism and increasing barriers to entry, particularly for resource-constrained businesses and new market entrants.

keyConcerns.title: Prison Time for Business License Transfers
keyConcerns.description: Transferring an ICT business license without NITA's approval carries **5-10 years imprisonment** plus mandatory business closure—an extraordinarily harsh penalty for what should be an administrative matter. The law provides **no criteria for approval decisions, no hearing rights, and no appeal before license revocation**, giving NITA arbitrary power over normal business transactions like mergers, acquisitions, or succession planning. This effectively **criminalizes standard business operations** and creates severe chilling effects on investment, startup acquisitions, and capital restructuring across Ghana's entire ICT sector.

keyConcerns.title: Equipment Seizure Without Due Process or Clear Standards
keyConcerns.description: NITA can **immediately confiscate ICT equipment** based on undefined triggers like lacking "necessary documentation" or attempting to "bypass regulatory oversight"—**without prior notice, hearing, or opportunity to cure violations**. This destroys businesses instantly based on vague standards that NITA interprets at its discretion. Comparable democracies require warnings, graduated enforcement, and pre-seizure hearings before confiscating business assets, particularly for documentation deficiencies that could be easily remedied.

keyConcerns.title: Guilty Until Proven Innocent for Corporate Officers
keyConcerns.description: This provision **reverses the burden of proof in criminal cases**, presuming that directors, managers, officers, and even **shareholders are criminally liable** for any corporate offense unless they can prove they exercised "due diligence" to prevent it. This violates the **presumption of innocence** fundamental to criminal justice—defendants must prove their innocence rather than prosecutors proving guilt. Combined with penalties up to **20 years imprisonment** and undefined "due diligence" standards, this creates severe legal uncertainty and risk for anyone involved in ICT businesses, particularly shareholders who may have no operational control.

keyConcerns.title: Criminal Penalties for Undefined "Critical Data" Violations
keyConcerns.description: Section 97(4) imposes **up to 7 years imprisonment** for hosting "critical data" without accreditation—but the law never defines what qualifies as **"critical data"** or what accreditation standards apply. This violates the fundamental principle that people must be able to know what conduct is criminal before facing prosecution. A cloud provider, data analytics firm, or business handling customer information cannot determine whether their data is "critical" until NITA decides, potentially after the fact. Combined with vague standards for **"negligently causes a cybersecurity breach"** (5 years) and undefined **"fraudulent ICT practices"** (10 years), businesses face severe criminal liability for technical violations they cannot reliably identify in advance.

keyConcerns.title: Criminal Penalties for Unlicensed Software Development
keyConcerns.description: This provision makes it a **criminal offense punishable by up to 2 years imprisonment** to operate any ICT business—including software development or service provision—without a government license. In most democracies, unlicensed business operation is an administrative matter handled through civil penalties, not criminal prosecution. The provision extends licensing requirements far beyond typical practice: while telecommunications infrastructure commonly requires authorization, **software developers and service providers in OECD countries generally don't need licenses to operate**—they're subject to conduct-based regulation instead. This creates significant barriers to entrepreneurship and innovation, as startups face criminal risk for developing products without first navigating NITA's licensing process.

keyConcerns.title: Criminal Imprisonment for Licensing Violations
keyConcerns.description: This provision makes licensing violations a **criminal offense punishable by 6 months to 2 years imprisonment**, rather than handling them through administrative penalties as is standard in democratic systems. A startup founder who operates a cloud service or data center without navigating NITA's licensing process could face **jail time**—not just fines or license suspension. Combined with the bill's expansive licensing requirements, citizenship restrictions, and vague scope definitions, this criminalizes market entry barriers and creates extreme chilling effects on entrepreneurship and innovation.

keyConcerns.title: License Suspension Based on Investigation Alone
keyConcerns.description: The Authority can **suspend an ICT business license simply because an investigation is underway**, without requiring formal charges, probable cause, or any finding of wrongdoing. This violates the **presumption of innocence** and creates severe risks: authorities could strategically initiate investigations to disrupt competitors or critics, while startups and small businesses face potential destruction even if ultimately exonerated. The provision's **"an offence...is being investigated"** language provides no safeguards against arbitrary enforcement or requirement that suspension be necessary to prevent harm.

keyConcerns.title: Government Contracts Locked to Citizen-Only Providers
keyConcerns.description: Public institutions must procure ICT services **only from NITA-certified providers**, but the bill's citizenship restrictions mean only **Ghanaian citizens or fully citizen-owned entities** can obtain ICT licenses and certifications. This creates a triple barrier: foreign companies cannot get licensed, cannot employ uncertified professionals, and cannot access government contracts—effectively locking international providers out of Ghana's public sector ICT market. While procurement preferences exist in other democracies, this goes further by combining certification requirements with absolute citizenship restrictions, eliminating competition from foreign firms regardless of their technical capabilities or competitive pricing.

keyConcerns.title: Undefined Directives Enable Arbitrary Business Shutdowns
keyConcerns.description: NITA can issue undefined **"directives"** and demand unspecified **"required information"** from any ICT business, then impose fines of USD 1,200-3,000 for non-compliance. If fines aren't paid, the Authority can **revoke licenses or ban companies from the entire ICT sector**. This creates a cascading enforcement mechanism where vague trigger language leads to business-ending consequences, giving NITA broad discretionary power to shut down companies without clear standards for what constitutes compliance.

keyConcerns.title: Undefined Certification Standards for All ICT Workers
keyConcerns.description: This provision requires **all ICT professionals in both public and private sectors** to obtain NITA certification before employment, but provides **no statutory criteria** for what qualifications are required or how certification decisions are made. NITA has complete discretion to determine standards, with no appeal mechanism specified. Combined with the bill's severe penalties (up to 20 years imprisonment), this creates a rule of law problem: employers and professionals must comply with undefined requirements or face serious consequences. This could create workforce bottlenecks, increase startup costs, and enable arbitrary enforcement—particularly problematic given NITA's financial incentives from service fees.

provisions.title: Establishment of the National Information Technology Authority
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision creates the National Information Technology Authority as a legal entity. The Authority has the power to own property, make contracts, and manage its affairs. The Authority can acquire land needed for its operations, with the Authority responsible for covering the costs.
provisions.rawText:
1. (1) There is established by this Act, the National Information Technology Authority as a body corporate.

(2)  The  Authority  may,  for  the  performance  of  its  functions  acquire  and  hold  property, dispose of property and enter into a contract or any other related transaction.

(3) Where there is a hindrance to the acquisition of land, the land may be acquired for the Authority under the Land Act, 2020 (Act 1036) and the cost shall be borne by the Authority.

provisions.title: Object of the Authority
provisions.plainLanguage: The Authority aims to guide the growth of technology and digital services in Ghana to support the country's progress. It will focus on making sure that the country has quality technology, efficient services, and well-trained ICT professionals working for the government. This will be achieved through regulation, coordination, and promotion of the ICT sector.
provisions.rawText:
2. The object of the Authority is to regulate, coordinate, promote, and develop information and communications technology and digital services in Ghana in line with national development goals and to

    - (a) ensure the provision of quality information and communications technology,

    - (b) promote  standards  of  efficiency  and  ensure  high  quality  of  service  in  the Information and Communications Technology ecosystem, and

    - (c) coordinate the management and development of information and communications technology personnel or practitioners in the public services

provisions.title: Functions of the Authority
provisions.plainLanguage: This section details the Authority's broad responsibilities in Ghana's ICT sector. It is responsible for licensing, regulating, and setting standards for ICT infrastructure, services, and professionals. The Authority also coordinates ICT policy, promotes fair competition, resolves disputes, and protects consumer interests, ensuring responsible and secure technology use across the country.

provisions.title: Powers of the Authority
provisions.plainLanguage: The Authority has the power to contract for necessary goods and services. It can also invest its funds with the Finance Minister's approval. Additionally, the Authority can publish information, fund training for people in the ICT industry, and conduct or promote research and development related to its functions.

provisions.title: Regulatory and best practice of the Authority
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision directs the Authority to operate with transparency, accountability, and consistency, while also following best practices in ICT regulation. It emphasizes protecting the rights and interests of digital service users, including data protection and value for money. The Authority must also consider the environmental impact of ICT infrastructure and promote competition and innovation, especially for Ghanaian tech companies. Finally, the Authority needs to consider both urban and rural communities and adhere to international ICT standards.

provisions.title: Governing body of the Authority
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision establishes the Board of Directors for the Authority, specifying its members. The board includes representatives from government ministries, ICT professionals, and experts in fields like digital innovation, law, and economics. The President appoints the board members, and the board must include at least three women.

provisions.title: Functions of the Board of Directors
provisions.plainLanguage: The Board of Directors is responsible for guiding the Authority's strategic direction. They must also make sure the Authority achieves its goals and operates efficiently. This ensures the Authority is well-managed and meets its intended purpose.
provisions.rawText:
- The Board of Directors shall

          - (a) exercise general oversight responsibility for the strategic direction of the Authority;

          - (b) ensure the achievement of the object of the Authority; and

          - (c) ensure  the  effective  and  efficient  performance  of  the  functions  of  the Authority.

provisions.title: Duties and liabilities of a member of the Board of Directors
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision defines the responsibilities and potential liabilities of Board members. Board members must act in the best interest of the Authority, similar to company directors, and avoid conflicts of interest or misusing information. They are generally prohibited from daily management and can be held liable for damages resulting from their actions.
provisions.rawText:
- 8 (1) A member of the Board of Directors has the same fiduciary relationship with the Authority and the same duty to act with loyalty and in good faith as a director of a company incorporated under the Companies Act, 2019 (Act 992).

    - Without limiting subsection (1), a member of the Board of Directors has a duty (a) to  act  honestly  and  in  the  best  interest  of  the  Authority  in  the performance of the functions of the Authority;

          - (c) not to disclose information acquired in the capacity of the member as a member of the Board of Directors to any person or make use of that information, except in the performance of functions;

          - (d) not to abuse the position of the office; and

          - (e) not to pursue personal interests at the expense of the Authority.

(3) A member of the Board of Directors, other than the Director General, shall not participate in the day-to-day running of the Authority.

(4) Where a court determines that the Authority has suffered a loss or damage as a result of the act or omission of a member of the Board of Directors, the court may, in addition to imposing a fine, order the member to pay appropriate compensation to the Authority.

provisions.title: Tenure of office of members of the Board of Directors
provisions.plainLanguage: Members of the Board of Directors serve four-year terms and can be reappointed for one additional term. A member may resign or be removed under certain conditions, such as missing three consecutive meetings. If a vacancy occurs, the President will appoint a replacement to serve the remainder of the term.

(3) The quorum for a meeting of the Board of Directors is seven members.

(6) The Board of Directors may co-opt a person to attend a meeting of the Board of Directors but that person shall not vote on a matter for decision at the meeting.

(7) The proceedings of the Board of Directors shall not be invalidated by reason of a vacancy  among  the  members  or  a  defect  in  the  appointment  or  qualification  of  a member

(8) Subject to this section, the Board of Directors may determine the procedure for the meeting of the Board of Directors.

provisions.title: Disclosure of interest
provisions.plainLanguage: This section requires board members to disclose any personal interest they have in a matter being discussed by the board. If a board member has a conflict of interest, they cannot participate in the board's discussion or vote on the matter. Failure to disclose a conflict or participating despite having one will result in removal from the board and recovery of any benefits gained.
provisions.rawText:

            - (a) shall disclose in writing the nature of that interest and the disclosure shall form part of the record of the consideration of the matter; and

            - (b) is disqualified from being present at or participating in the deliberations of the Board of Directors in respect of that matter.

(2) A member of the Board shall inform the Authority of any change in respect of that member's registrable interest from the date of the change.

(3) A member who without reasonable excuse fails to declare a registrable interest, or knowingly makes a false declaration, contravenes subsections (1) and (2), ceases to be a  member  of  the  Board  and  the  appointment  of  the  member  to  the  Board  shall  be revoked by the President

provisions.title: Establishment of committees
provisions.plainLanguage: This section allows the Board of Directors to create committees, which can include both members of the board and outside advisors. Committees with non-board members must be chaired by a board member. The board is required to establish a Technical Committee, Audit Committee, and Risk Committee, and will define what these committees do and who serves on them.
provisions.rawText:
13. (1) The Board of Directors may establish committees or advisory bodies consisting of members of the Board of Directors, non-members, or both, to perform a function of the Board of Directors.

(2)  A  committee  composed  of  members  and  non-members  of  the  Board  of Directors shall be chaired by a member of the Board of Directors.

(3) A committee composed exclusively of non-members may only advise the Board

    - Without limiting subsection (1), the Board of Directors shall establish the following committees:

              - (b) Audit Committee; and

              - (c) Risk Committee.
